data.name: Abbey Ale
data.description: A traditional Belgian abbey ale, the sweetness with a gentle finish masks the powerful punch it packs.

style.name: Belgian-Style Table Beer
style.description: These ales and lagers are very low in alcohol and historically in Belgium enjoyed with meals by both adults and children. Pale to very dark brown in color. Additions of caramel coloring are sometimes employed to adjust color. They are light bodied with relatively low carbonation with limited aftertaste. The mouth feel is light to moderate, though higher than one might anticipate, usually because of unfermented sugars/malt sugars. Malted barley, wheat and rye may be used as well as unmalted wheat, rye, oats and corn. A mild malt character could be evident. Aroma/Flavor hops are most commonly used to employ a flavor balance that is only low in bitterness. Traditional versions do not use artificial sweeteners nor are they excessively sweet. More modern versions of this beer incorporate sweeteners such as sugar and saccharine added post fermentation to sweeten the palate and add to a perception of smoothness. Spices (such as orange and lemon peel, as well as coriander) may be added in barely perceptible amounts, but this is not common. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Competition directors may choose to break out subcategories of Traditional and Modern.

breweries.name: Forge Brew Works
breweries.description: Forge Brew Works is a Northern Virginia Micro Brewery opening in Summer of 2013

data.name: Abbey Single Belgian Table Beer
data.description: The recipe may be simple, but our Belgian table beer is anything but.  Delicate hints of spice mingle with banana and fruit esters to round out this subtle, yet complex beer.  With its refined body and lower alcohol, our table beer makes a great aperitif but can also be enjoyed with lighter fare.

available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

breweries.name: Odin Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Odin Brewing embraces the exploratory spirit of the ancient Vikings.  We set sail in December 2009, during the height of a global economic storm, and have quickly become one of the fastest growing breweries in Washington, with our beer is now sacking and pillaging cities throughout Washington and British Columbia. We have taken a different tack than many new brewers, and rather than going for a number of very big, single batch beers, we are focused on food-friendly beers in a smaller lineup that is readily available year round. We realized a long time ago that food-friendly by no means needs to be less flavorful, and we actually add ingredients to widen the palate of our beers above and beyond their original styles.

To better integrate with a meal and make our beers more ‘sessionable’ in general, we utilize highly attenuating yeasts to dry out our beers to make them less sweet and filling, then replace that desired sweetness with an addition outside the norm, such as Juniper, Ginger or even Angelica. These ingredients are always kept at a level to avoid building a ‘spice beer’, and always present themselves as a unique and complementary addition. We also focus on extremely clean finishes, and use the entire recipe to build bittering rather than just using the hops to reduce lingering starchiness.

In the end, the true beauty of any flavor is in the eye (and mouth) of the beholder. Read about our beers here, then taste them at your local restaurant or store and judge for yourself if we have truly crafted ‘Great Beer Designed With Great Food In Mind’. We believe we have.

locations.name: Tasting Room
locations.hoursOfOperation:
Wednesday - Friday: 3:00 pm – 10:00 pm
(From 1 August 2013: Monday – Friday: 3:00 pm – 10:00 pm)
Saturday & Sunday: 12:00 pm – 10:00 pm

data.name: Abbey's Single
data.description: A Belgian-style abbey ale crafted like those that Trappist monks brew for their own session beer. It is light bodied, light in color and relatively lower in alcohol with spicy phenolics and complex fruity esters of cherries, nectarines, peaches and bubblegum with a characteristic slightly tart and dry finish from the Belgian yeast.

breweries.name: DESTIHL Brewery
breweries.description: DESTIHL opened its first gastrobrewpub (DESTIHL Restaurant & Brew Works) in Normal, IL in November 2007 and added its second gastrobrewpub in downtown Champaign in April 2011, where the company focuses on both artisan food and beers.  DESTIHL’s 20,000sf production brewery project in Bloomington, IL commenced in September 2012 with brewing starting in May 2013 and includes a 25-barrel brewhouse, several large fermenters and 100,000 cubic feet of barrel-aging space. It has taken countless hours to develop the unique concept that is now DESTIHL, where the brewery team utilizes both global brewing traditions and new American craft brewing ingenuity and artisanship to make uncommon beers uncommonly well.

data.name: Bavaro
data.description:
In the past, table beer was commonplace on family tables. 

This is actually not as strange as it sounds. Table beer contains vitamins and fewer calories than the majority of soft drinks.  Furthermore a table beer can be very flavoursome and its low alcohol is in its favour.

breweries.name: Haacht
breweries.description: Started in 1893 as a dairy farm. Eugène de Ro brewed his first top-fermented beer in 1898. 4 years later he was also brewing bottom-fermented beers. In 1929 the dairy closed, so the brewery was able to expand production into other types of beers: Bock, Export, Pilsner and Stout Ale. In 1950 they established their first bottling plant. Up until then the beer was only being sold in kegs. Between 1968 and 1990 they've been expanding by taking over breweries in the south of the Netherlands and North of France. In the 1990's they've started modernising the brewery. In 2010 this modernisation process was completed when they inaugurated their new kegigng hall. They're currently the third biggest pilsner brewery in Belgium.

data.name: Belgian Brune
data.description: Belgian style brown made with dark Belgian candi syrup. Notes of dried fruits (fig/dates) with a creamy mouthfeel and slightly sweet finish.
data.foodPairings: Smoked trout, ham, chorizo, glazed ribs, Chinese food and savory desserts.

breweries.name: Living The Dream Brewing Co.
breweries.description:
We are a dog friendly brewery & taproom located in Highlands Ranch, Colorado. 

Multiple beers brewed year long to quench your thirst during any activity. From a vigorous game of badminton to an afternoon of rev-ing your 2-stroke noise maker at a Nascar race, we've got ya covered.

breweries.description: The concept for Nighthawk Brewery started on January 2, 2011 when Ethan Hall & Jay Mead did the first home brew at Ethan's home on Nighthawk Circle. Jokingly, "if we even open our own brewery, we HAVE to call it Nighthawk Brewery..."

data.name: Burton Bridge Tickle Brain Ale
data.description:
Replica of an Abbey style beer. Ticklebrain was a Tudor name for strong ale.

Colour: Brown
Nose: Estery
Taste: Smooth & Powerful
Hops: Northdown
Malt: Pale with Chocolate

breweries.name: Evil Czech Brewery
breweries.description:
Evil Czech has been operating since 2011 and opened it's doors to a new 20 barrel facility in 2014.

... sometimes for beer to be good, it has to get evil.

data.name: Cutty Can't Hang!
data.description: This Belgian table bier is a traditional entry into the Session category. It is meant to be consumed with food but also stands well on its own. When you need to drink the whole meal and want something with plenty of flavor but don’t want to get shit-twisted from the alcohol, this is a great choice. Look for a smooth malty body with hints of biscuit and rye. The hops are subdued and mostly present as a bittering agent. The yeast plays a prominent role in creating bready and lightly fruity notes.

breweries.name: Against The Grain Brewery
breweries.description:
Louisville's only brewer-owned brewery is, like most worthwhile undertakings, the product of dissatisfaction with the status quo. The Louisville area has had a number of quality brewpubs for some time now, but still there was simply not enough beer! Against the Grain is an effort to help solve this problem. We maintain a diverse array of beers covering all of the major categories of beer flavor while generating an endless stream of innovative new brews. In short, everything is "specialty" Boredom will be extremely difficult.

Our food is designed with same philosophy as our brewing. Fresh and interesting smokehouse fare with a gastropub flare lets us bring you the very best flavors to stand alone and to compliment our beers. Regular menu changes allow us to take full advantage of the best seasonal ingredients, our chef's whim, and optimal pairing with our dynamic beer list.

Throw your preconceived notions right the hell out the window. We aren't just another brewpub. We are Against the Grain!

data.name: DEFCON V BELGIAN TABLE BEER
data.description: FACTION DEFCON V BELGIAN TABLE BEER IS AN EASY DRINKING BELGIAN-STYLE TABLE BEER BREWED W/ ENGLISH HOPS & BELGIAN MALT & YEAST

data.name: EBE
data.description: Hebe, daughter of Zeus and Hera, the sister of Ares and of Ilizia, is a symbol of eternal youth and vitality. Handmaid of the gods pours the nectar in golden cups at their banquet, the brewery is the idea of ​​youth and carbonation, the predominant character of this beer.
data.foodPairings: Ideal as an aperitif accompanied by appetizers tasted fried or with cheese ripened seeds. Impressing with fish or shellfish.

data.name: Enkel
data.description: This is the brewer’s beer. Enkel is the name for the table beer at many brewing monasteries. Our’s has malted spelt  for a creamy grain character and rich body, as well as malted rye for it’s characteristic spiciness.

breweries.name: The Commons Brewery
breweries.description: The Commons Brewery is a small craft brewery located in Southeast Portland, Oregon.

data.name: Enkel
data.description: Traditionally brewed as a table beer in monasteries, the Enkel is a session ale meant to accompany your meal. A brett presence paired with a traditional Abbey Ale strain provides unexpected tropical fruit notes.

data.name: Farnam House Grisette
data.description: An old world, Belgian-style ale brewed with wheat as well as barley malt.  It is a light, session saison that is low in alcohol and refreshing, yet full of flavor.

breweries.name: Farnam House Brewing Company
breweries.description: Farnam House Brewing Company is an exciting new brewpub located in Midtown Omaha at 3562 Farnam St. Farnam House specializes in farmhouse ales and barrel aged beers and offers a diverse food menu made with locally-sourced ingredients and beer-infused creations.

data.name: Le Petit Prince
data.description: A clear and simple expression of the delicate interplay between noble hops and farmhouse yeast. Throughout Northern Europe, light-bodied, well-hopped, low alcohol table beers were often the beverage of choice with all meals at times and in places where the water wasn’t always safe to drink.

breweries.name: Jester King Craft Brewery
breweries.description: Located in the beautiful Texas Hill Country, Jester King Craft Brewery is an authentic farmhouse brewery committed to brewing artisan ales of great depth and character. At times drawing influences from the world beyond traditional brewers’ yeast, Jester King’s beer is not rushed to market but allowed to mature – often in oak barrels – to create the most enjoyable, interesting and exciting beer we can make. An additional layer of complexity is added to Jester King’s bottled beers by allowing a second fermentation to take place in the bottle. As part of its commitment to sustainability, the slow food movement and Texas, Jester King beer uses as many organic and local ingredients as possible and will soon be brewed with harvested rainwater.

data.name: Maltosa
data.description:
In the past, table beer was commonplace on family tables.
This is actually not as strange as it sounds. Table beer contains vitamins and fewer calories than the majority of soft drinks.  Furthermore a table beer can be very flavoursome and its low alcohol is in its favour. 

'Maltosa' is a brown table beer that contains just 1.2% alcohol.

data.name: Proto Gradus
data.description: Belgian-inspired Single, subtle floral hop layered with fruity yeast aroma. Bready maltiness, slightly citric with a light body, but distinctly yeast forward. Crisp, clean, and quenching, as was intended..

Competition directors may choose to break out subcategories of Traditional and Modern.

breweries.name: Penrose Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Art, Science, and Belgian-Inspired Brewing in Geneva, IL. 

This began with a shared obsession for skillfully brewed beer, and the starved need for cultural redirection of our lifework. Blissfully content with an opportunity to help refine a discerning palate, preferably with beer in hand, a deeper passion and commitment to the cause has evolved into Penrose Brewing Company. The cultural shift already underway is a by-product of intention and specificity. You will want to be involved.

data.name: Saisonita
data.description: table farmhouse ale

style.name: Belgian-Style Table Beer
style.description: These ales and lagers are very low in alcohol and historically in Belgium enjoyed with meals by both adults and children. Pale to very dark brown in color. Additions of caramel coloring are sometimes employed to adjust color. They are light bodied with relatively low carbonation with limited aftertaste. The mouth feel is light to moderate, though higher than one might anticipate, usually because of unfermented sugars/malt sugars. Malted barley, wheat and rye may be used as well as unmalted wheat, rye, oats and corn. A mild malt character could be evident. Aroma/Flavor hops are most commonly used to employ a flavor balance that is only low in bitterness. Traditional versions do not use artificial sweeteners nor are they excessively sweet. More modern versions of this beer incorporate sweeteners such as sugar and saccharine added post fermentation to sweeten the palate and add to a perception of smoothness. Spices (such as orange and lemon peel, as well as coriander) may be added in barely perceptible amounts, but this is not common. Diacetyl should not be perceived. Competition directors may choose to break out subcategories of Traditional and Modern.

breweries.name: Monkish Brewing Co
breweries.description: A small craft brewery in Los Angeles (Torrance), California creating artisanal beers inspired by Belgian-ish farmhouse and monastic brewing traditions and philosophy.

data.name: Saving Grace Table Beer
data.description: Based on the Belgian “patersbier” which Trappist monks used to brew for sustenance that would allow them to continue to work during the day. This low-alcohol farmhouse beer is brewed with Pilsner malt, Czech Saaz hops and our house Saison yeast to provide a satisfying end to a long day of hard work.

data.name: Skibsol
data.description: Our ship's beer looks to the forgotten tradition of Scandinavian table beers. This smoky old style was brewed to sustain hardy Danish seafarers. Brewed with rye, as well as a combination of smoked malts.

style.name: Belgian-Style Table Beer

breweries.name: Right Proper Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Right Proper Brewing Company will be a locally owned neighborhood brew pub in a Washington DC neighborhood

Washington, DC, needs at least two things: more affordable neighborhood restaurants, and at least one locally owned brewpub. 
Our objective is three-fold: We want to create a neighborhood gathering place that makes and serves well-priced delicious food and amazing fresh beer; we want to help our neighborhood thrive by investing in the community and its residents; and we want to anchor Washington, DC on the map as a destination for craft beer. Our business will invest in the growth and development of our employees as well as of our community.

We’ll take an innovative approach to small scale, “yeast-forward” craft brewing to produce artisanal ales and lagers in a comfortable, expertly designed casual old-world tavern. Serving fresh beer and affordable, high-quality American food, Right Proper will be a focus of pride for its neighborhood.

breweries.name: Thirsty Monk Pub & Brewery
breweries.description: Asheville's Premier Craft Beer Bar

data.name: Solitaire
data.description: Our 2012 Replicale submission to the Illinois Craft Brewers Guild. This year, 15 Illinois breweries made a similar base beer, each choosing a different Belgian ale yeast for fermentation. The yeast we chose is clean, with good ester fruitiness and a lightly tart complexity. It is light-medium bodied with a dry finish and medium hop bitterness, and at 4.7%, it is a refreshing and sessionable Belgian-style ale.

breweries.name: Revolution Brewing
breweries.description:
Revolution Brewing is Chicago's new hometown craft brewery. Our brewpub in Logan Square is a bustling, neighborhood institution where friends and families meet to enjoy the freshest beer in town. Opening our brewery has been a labor of love. We think you can see that in everything we do ranging from the details of our carved fists holding up our mahogany bar to the pungent hop aroma of our Anti-Hero IPA to our creative dishes like our bacon-fat popcorn.

The growth of craft breweries in the U.S. has been nothing short of a revolution and we're proud to be standing tall in this new crowd. The changing tastes of beer drinkers demand bigger flavors and more variety. That's exactly what we give you at Revolution Brewing. Our brewpub produces about 50 different beer styles each year. We've got session beers like Workingman Mild, hop-bombs like Double Fist and more bourbon barrel aged beers than you can shake a stave at. We have fun doing what we do and invite you to come in and join us.

style.name: Belgian-Style Table Beer

The mouth feel is light to moderate, though higher than one might anticipate, usually because of unfermented sugars/malt sugars. breweries.name: Sierra Nevada Brewing Company
breweries.description:
The Sierra Nevada Brewing Company was established in 1980 by homebrewers Ken Grossman and Paul Camusi. Camusi retired in 1998 and sold his share in the company to Grossman.

Located in Chico, California, Sierra Nevada Brewing is one of the most popular craft breweries currently operating in the United States. Its Pale Ale is world renowned, and the brewery produces almost 700,000 barrels of beer per year. Sierra Nevada's Pale Ale is the second best-selling craft beer in the United States, behind the Boston Beer Company's Samuel Adams Boston Lager.

Sierra Nevada's specialty brews include the winter seasonal Celebration, which is similar to the pale ale, but hoppier; and Summerfest, a lager which is citrusy and sunny.

breweries.name: Grist Iron Brewing Co.
breweries.description: Opening in the spring of 2015, Grist Iron Brewing Company will join a growing league of fine craft beer artisans along the shores of Seneca Lake, NY.  We are being deliberate with every detail that goes into the design of the brewery from the craft beers on tap to the music on the stereo so we can make sure that Grist Iron Brewing is a place you'll want to return. Food is important so along with a fantastic craft beer selection, made by brewer and co-owner Patrick Palmer, we will have two brick ovens serving as the foundation for our signature menu using as many fresh, local ingredients as possible.

data.name: Table Beer
data.description: A sessionable Belgian in the tradition of the Trappist brewer’s beers. This 4.0%ABV beer is citrusy, peppery, and refreshing. It pairs nicely with a turkey dinner or a sunny afternoon in the back yard.
data.foodPairings: Really anything, standouts include: soft goat cheese, sweet potato, puff pastry/ wellingtons, cake with buttercream.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

breweries.name: Benchmark Brewing Company
breweries.description: Benchmark Brewing is all about delicious beer, beer that we want to take home and drink. We want consistently awesome beer that you can rely on to be the gold standard of the style.  Our year round beers are low in alcohol and high in flavor; we often find that it is nice to be able to enjoy a beer or two and keep your wits about you.  We also know that there are times when a ten percent beer is just what you need to keep you warm at night; to that end we will celebrate the seasons, months, weeks, or whatever we feel needs celebration with specialty releases that will vary wildly in alcohol content and style.  No matter the style or strength all Benchmark Beer will set the standard for its kind.

locations.name: Benchmark Brewing Company
locations.hoursOfOperation:
Mon - Thurs: 3:00 pm - 8:00 pm
Fri & Sat: noon - 8:00 pm
Sun: noon - 6pm

data.name: Tafelbier
data.description:
While most savvy beer consumers have heard of Belgian Dubbels, Tripels and Quadruples, few have ever had a Belgian-style Enkel, meaning “Single”. This is an ale rarely, if ever, brewed on the West Coast, let alone America.

Typically, Tafelbier (Table Beer) is brewed only at Trappist Monasteries for the monks to enjoy with meals. They often drink only half a bottle with lunch and the rest with supper, despite the beer’s low alcohol content. Our Tafelbier is modest in strength, robed in warm, golden hues and soft on the palate with a smooth, dry finish.

available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

breweries.name: Ritual Brewing Co.
breweries.description: Fresh and Flavorful Craft Beer in Redlands, California.

data.name: Tafelbier
data.description: Tafelbier is a Belgian beer of lower strength - and for good reason. Tafelbier was, (and still is) enjoyed by Belgian families at meal time. This is the ultimate summer session beer at 2.8% ABV. Dry hopped with Styrian Goldings and Saaz hops, it has a distinct herbal hop aroma and flavor that balances perfectly with the spicy Belgian yeast character.

style.name: Belgian-Style Table Beer
style.description: These ales and lagers are very low in alcohol and historically in Belgium enjoyed with meals by both adults and children. Pale to very dark brown in color. Additions of caramel coloring are sometimes employed to adjust color. They are light bodied with relatively low carbonation with limited aftertaste. The mouth feel is light to moderate, though higher than one might anticipate, usually because of unfermented sugars/malt sugars. breweries.name: Notch Brewing
breweries.description:
There is a myth born of the craft beer movement that flavorful beer is synonymous with high alcohol. The art of brewing great beer in the US without a debilitating ABV had seemed all but dead. Not anymore. Myths are simply myths, and beers of great flavor and quality have been brewed for hundreds of years in every great brewing nation except ours. Chris is not out to change the US craft beer world, but to simply brew the beers he loves to drink, and he thinks he is not alone.

Chris has been brewing professionally since 1993, first as an apprentice at Kennebunkport Brewing, then at the Tremont Brewery in Boston MA starting in 1994. Today, Chris is an independent brewer – he owns no facility – instead brewing and collaborating with other breweries. He currently brews his beers at two locations, the Ipswich Ale Brewery (Bottles & Draft) and Kennebunkport Brewery (Cask).

data.name: The Beer Formerly Known as LA TACHE
data.nameDisplay: The Beer Formerly Known as LA TACHE
data.description: The Beer Formerly Known as LA TACHE is the table sour produced year-round by The Ale Apothecary. (TBFKA) LA TACHE is made of malted barley & wheat and Goschie Farms Cascade Hops. The hops are used only for aroma as the balance of the beer comes from acid produced by our house lactobacillus culture. She spends up to one year in our barrels during a long, relaxed fermentation prior to a month-long dry-hopping (yes, in oak barrels!). Our sensory experience is lemon citrus & fermented orchard fruit nose over earthy undertones. The palate finishes with soft lactic acid balanced by the malt body.

breweries.name: The Ale Apothecary
breweries.description: Producing the finest hand made beer using our own innovative brewing process, which melds the ancient art of brewing with traditions of wine & champagne production. With great ambition and intention, we open the window to mystery with every fermentation!

data.name: The Chapter House
data.description: Scholars labor and workmen read. Together they lay their burdens down, rough knuckles and penciled cuffs brush as handshake greetings welcome the congregants. Join us at the Chapter House as the sun fades far away in the crimson of the west. Joy to all we love the best! Enjoy our Belgian style red ale, malty & clean.
data.foodPairings: Pair with an evening song, a deep dish pizza or a philly cheese steak.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

breweries.name: The Black Abbey Brewing Company
breweries.description: “St. Anne, help me! I will become a monk!” Thus cried Martin Luther as a summer thunderstorm bore down on him in Stotternheim, Germany in 1505. These words marked the beginning of a momentous shift in religious history, but as you’re about to see, they led to some great beer, too.

breweries.name: Burial Beer Co.
breweries.description: Burial Beer Co meticulously crafts ales and lagers from their Asheville brewery. We specialize in Belgian ales and German lagers, while also making American IPAs and Stouts. Come visit our ramshackle joint on Asheville's South Slope and try some of the wares.

data.name: The Special
data.description: A traditional monastic style, brewed by the brothers to be shared at the table. Garnet hues of evening skies darkening to night. The smell of baking bread and evening flowers. The Special harkens to times of peace, quiet conversation and friendly fellowship. {Belgian-style mild} 5.8% ABV 13 IBUs
data.foodPairings: This beer pairs well with flavorful cheese and meat.
